section.title: Net Business
section.para: There is considerable variation in the way the nets in the Section conduct business. In most cases, there is no need for these differences.

section.title: Announcements
section.para: Announcements should be made after all checkins, but before other net business. NCS should try to arrange announcements to occur when all (or most) of the checkins are present. Since traffic on CW is generally passed off-frequency and often routed as listed, it can take careful planning on the part of NCS to ensure all members have an opportunity to hear the announcement.

section.title: Traffic
section.para: Traffic should be handled after all checkins and any announcements. Some nets are tempted to move traffic during checkins, but this is generally not desireable unless traffic is being handled off-frequency. Stations want to get checked in as quickly as possible, and leave if there is no traffic for them. Handling traffic on-frequency before all stations have checked in simply wastes time for stations that are not yet checked in.

One obvious exception is when a net liaison has short time. There are occasions when a liaison needs to get traffic for a downstream net passed early so that the liaison can get to the downstream net. On phone, it is often difficult to find another frequency to pass that traffic, but NCS should endeavor to find an alternate frequency if possible.

Net control should consider the most effective way to route the traffic. Traffic should be organized to get as many stations done with the net business as possible, as early as possible. When a pair of stations have a long list of traffic, that traffic should be handled last in order to get other stations checked out. Obviously, other constraints such as later nets and short time stations must be considered.

NCS should strive to become familiar with regular checkins and their capabilities. Often, two stations within VHF simplex range can be sent to two meters to pass traffic off the net frequency. Repeaters can be used when repeater owners are amenable to using their machines for traffic.

section.title: Routing Traffic
section.para: Net control should strive to route traffic in an effective fashion, with an eye toward sharing the burden where possible. It can be discouraging to show up at a net night after night and have all traffic sent to another station.
On the other hand, NCS should assume that net liaison stations are willing to accept traffic bound for that net. This is especially true of Eighth Region and NWS reps.

Some net controls are reluctant to route traffic to stations who will deliver it via a calling plan. Certainly, it is preferable that traffic be delivered by a station close to the destination. However, except for HXG traffic, messages should not be delayed simply because the net control doesn't like how it will be delivered. Even HXG traffic should not be excessively delayed simply because NCS does not agree with the form of delivery. Nevertheless, it is preferable to find a local station for delivery where that does not unduly delay the traffic.

section.title: Training Topics
section.para: Training Topics Some nets have regular training topics. Generally, these should be transmitted after other net business, except in the case of nets whose primary purpose is training (e.g. QMN TN).

QNC Training topics should be introduced as formal QNCs where possible. This has a number of advantages:
The formal QNC sends a signal to the membership that the delivering station has spent the time to prepare the topic in a concise, well-thought-out fashion.
Stations have a clean way to file and organize training topics for future reference.
Stations also have a convenient way to re-use the training topic in a later training session with a different group.
The delivering station has a convenient way of keeping track of what topics have been delivered.
Students get the additional practice of copying formal traffic.

section.title: Over vs. Out
section.para:
The recent influx of MARS members to the nets has caused more amateurs to return to the proper use of the prowords Over and Out which had fallen into disuse in recent years. Net controls should set an example for all stations, including appropriate use of these prowords.
Over Over means "I am finished transmitting and expect a reply from you".
Out Out means "I am finished transmitting and I do not expect a direct reply from you".

section.title: Roger and Wilco
section.para: MARS Roger Wilco Many stations also misuse the term Roger which means "I have received and understood your transmission". Recently more stations replace the Roger with the MARS term Wilco, which means "Will comply". This is the preferred use when your intention is not only to acknowledge receipt, but your intention to comply.
